description: This collection uses primary sources to explore the Hudson River School.

isRelatedTo.name: An 1872 oil painting called *Lake George* by Jasper Francis Cropsey, a first-generation Hudson River school painter.
*Hudson River Landscape*, ca.1870-1875, painted by Homer Dodge Martin, who is thought to have coined the name “Hudson River school.”
A brief description of the Hudson River school and some of its most notable painters from *American Landscape Painters*, 1913.
*Sunset (California Scenery)* by Albert Bierstadt, 1864. One of the foremost Hudson River school painters, Bierstadt worked throughout the US.
An excerpt and illustration from *The homes of Ober-Ammergau*, 1872, by Eliza Pratt Greatorex.
An 1861 painting by Frederic Edwin Church, a renowned second-generation Hudson River school painter, and excerpt from an exhibition catalog.
An 1847 oil-on-paper study by Frederic Edwin Church, called *Apotheosis to Thomas Cole*, showing Church’s esteem for his teacher.
*Sudden Shower, Newbury Marshes*, ca.1865-1875, by Martin Johnson Heade. Heade was a second-generation Hudson River school painter.
*Hook Mountain, Near Nyack, on the Hudson*, an 1866 oil painting by Sanford Robinson Gifford.
An 1859 oil painting called *Catskill Waterfall* by John Frederick Kensett.
An excerpt from *Proceedings at a Meeting of the Century Association, Held in Memory of John F. Kensett, December, 1872*.
*Santa Fe*, an 1866 oil painting by Thomas Worthington Whittredge. Whittredge traveled across the US as a landscape painter.
An excerpt from a 2002 interview with a Minnesota Institute of Art curator about an exhibition of nineteenth-century landscape artists.
A 2009 poster to celebrate national forests that uses a detail of Albert Bierstadt’s 1861 painting *Island Lake, Wind River Range, Wyoming*.

citation.text: Courtesy of Minneapolis Institute of Arts via Minnesota Digital Library.
Cole, Thomas, “Landscape,” Digital Public Library of America, https://dp.la/item/52f4d6171eef8eaa20208c7e894cd9ef.

hasPart.name: An excerpt and illustration from *The homes of Ober-Ammergau*, 1872, by Eliza Pratt Greatorex.
hasPart.text: Eliza Pratt Greatorex’s work was deeply influenced by the Hudson River school painters. This description from her diary of the German countryside (which reminds her of the Hudson Valley) reflects the relationship many artists had with nature at this time.

An excerpt from *Proceedings at a Meeting of the Century Association, Held in Memory of John F. Kensett, December, 1872*.
*Santa Fe*, an 1866 oil painting by Thomas Worthington Whittredge. Whittredge traveled across the US as a landscape painter.
An excerpt from a 2002 interview with a Minnesota Institute of Art curator about an exhibition of nineteenth-century landscape artists.

citation.text: Courtesy of United States Government Publishing Office (GPO).
“National forests, celebrate 100 years of conservation,” Digital Public Library of America, https://dp.la/item/4f287cc025385761a1eaa92e46c75ae6.

hasPart.name: A 2009 poster to celebrate national forests that uses a detail of Albert Bierstadt’s 1861 painting *Island Lake, Wind River Range, Wyoming*.
hasPart.text: The legacy and influence of the Hudson River school painters lives on today, as exemplified by this National Forest Service poster that uses a Bierstadt painting.

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Using the sources in this set, characterize the primary themes and subjects of Hudson River school painters. What did these artists paint? What ideas were they exploring?
2. The Hudson River school artists lived and worked in the first half of the nineteenth century. What connections do you see between the concerns of their art and other ideas of the moment? Specifically consider America’s westward expansion and manifest destiny, as well as romanticism in American literature. 
3. Examine [Thomas Cole’s landscape painting](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/the-hudson-river-school/sources/690). How does this piece explore the Hudson River school’s trademark idea of the pastoral?
4. Explore the many landscape pieces in this set. What does the landscape represent? How does its meaning change between paintings?
5. Using the [2009 poster](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/the-hudson-river-school/sources/704) as a jumping off point, discuss how the Hudson River school impacted Americans’ relationships to land and nature.

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Split students into groups of two. Ask each group to select two pieces of art from the set that express one of these three Hudson River school themes: exploration, discovery, and settlement. Ask each pair to plan a five-minute presentation in which they show the two pieces they’ve selected, comparing and contrasting how these two pieces approach the selected theme.

hasPart.name: Teaching Guide: Exploring the Hudson River School
Resources
hasPart.text:
1. [The Hudson River School](http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/hurs/hd_hurs.htm), The Metropolitan Museum of Art. 
2. [The Hudson River School: Nationalism, Romanticism, and the Celebration of the American Landscape](http://www.history.vt.edu/Barrow/Hist3144/readings/hudsonriver/), Virginia Tech. 
3. [A Brief History of Nature and the American Consciousness](http://xroads.virginia.edu/~cap/nature/cap2.html), Nature and American Identity, University of Virginia.

hasPart.name: Overview
hasPart.text: The Hudson River school was an artistic movement that often held up a romantic vision that humanity and nature can exist together peacefully. The American landscape—and its grandiosity—is the school’s predominant subject. Visions of the Hudson Valley, as well as naturalistic scenes from across the United States and beyond, are depicted in the paintings. Thomas Cole is widely considered the founder of the movement; Homer Dodge Martin, Frederick Edwin Church, and Albert Bierstadt are some of the most notable first- and second-generation Hudson River school painters. While the Hudson River school artists were American, many European artists picked up the themes of their work. Few women were part of the movement, although some, like Eliza Pratt Greatorex, were influenced by it. One offshoot of the Hudson River school was the Luminism movement, and many second-generation artists’ works are examples of both.
